pullRequest.body:
This PR adds the linter against `cases'`, operating exactly analogously to the linter against `refine'`.

Also move the `cases'` and `refine'` linters to the `Mathlib.Linter.Style` namespace. (The linters could be merged, as noted in a comment, but this will be left for another PR.)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [7f6fb52e06](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21832/commits/7f6fb52e067a8951da22eb277ae832e21d7d50ae)

Import changes exceeding 2%

| %      | File |
| -      | -    |
| +5.26% | `Mathlib.Init` |

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
There are 5960 files with changed transitive imports taking up over 248459 characters: this is too many to display!
You can run `scripts/import_trans_difference.sh all` locally to see the whole output.

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ casesLinter`
`+ getCases'`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

> Most importantly, you should also import this linter in `Mathlib.Init`: this will ensure every file in mathlib runs this syntax linter.

I can't do that; `cases'` is defined in `Mathlib.Tactic.Cases` (unlike `refine'`), and importing the linter in `Mathlib.Init` causes a build cycle.

Regardless of how the import situation will be fixed, I think that this is a great situation where we can merge the two linters, the `refine` and the `cases` linter.

The two options should be initialized, if at least one is `true`, then the relevant nodes are accumulated in two arrays, and depending on which option is active, the linter emits the appropriate warnings.

> The two options should be initialized, if at least one is `true`, then the relevant nodes are accumulated in two arrays, and depending on which option is active, the linter emits the appropriate warnings.

Before I perform the linter merge I would have to fix the import problem first.

The only declaration used in `Mathlib.Tactic.Cases` defined in Mathlib is `addLocalVarInfoForBinderIdent`. However, this last declaration is used in a bunch of "normal" mathlib files.

Do you need to import the `cases'` tactic in the linter?  Can you not use `` `....cases`` for the node-matching?  The tests can then import the actual tactic and make sure that the name of the node is correct.

>Can you not use `` `....cases `` for the node-matching? The tests can then import the actual tactic and make sure that the name of the node is correct.

How does that work?

I have a couple of minor comments; see below.
Most importantly, you should also import this linter in `Mathlib.Init`: this will ensure every file in mathlib runs this syntax linter.
Almost there! In case (ahem) the `ENatToNat` question ends up stalling this; feel free to split out the `refine'` change, I'm happy to approve this right away.

```suggestion
example (a : (True  True)  (True  True)) : True := by
```suggestion
I wonder if a test covering e.g. cases' in a sub-goal could be useful. Up to you.
I think this is fine enough.
Please move this line above the comment, thanks!

I think this linter should be in the `Mathlib.Linter.Style` namespace, and the option be called `linter.style.cases` (or even `linter.style.cases'`). I know you're just going off the refine' linter; that linter should also be moved.

```suggestion
    if kind == `Mathlib.Tactic.cases' then rargs.push stx else rargs
```
This does the matching, without checking that the name exists.

The test file can still import the `cases'` linter, though.

Note: I'm not at a computer, so I cannot really test this.
Committed the change.
I'm partial to removing this comment also: this is enforced by a mathlib linter anyway.
Can you say why this change is fine? To make a guess, is it because it only uses `cases'` with a single ident, and `cases` and `cases'` have the same behaviour in this case? Same question below.
Yes, that's correct (and the case names in the second replacement correspond with the given inductor). Where am I supposed to put this information?
I *think* the other PRs put the `register_option` outside of the style namespace. I'm not sure if that's a meaningful detail.
I'll just leave it as you suggested.

pullRequest.title: feat: the `cases'` linter
